Hi,

    So, further to my last post about alternative
speciestion, I wanted to discuss the case where you
have two species and want to merge them back together,
in such a way as to obtain the maximum fitness in the
merged species.

    Obviously the nature of this merge depends a lot
on how closely related the two species are.  If they
are too similar, then there is nothing to gain from
merging, and the merge might even consist of merely
relabelling two sets of individuals as a single set.

    Equally, if the two species are totally
dissimilar, then merging them may not make sense. 
OTOH, if you regarded the process as forming a
symbiosis, rather than direct cross-breeding (and
assuming your system supports that in some way) then
two dissimilar species could co-evolve so as to work
together and achieve a higher fitness than either
acting alone.

    As long as we're not not discussing concrete
details of any system, the distinction between
cross-breeding and the formation of a symbiosis is
fairly semantic anyway.  And as my thesis in this
message is going to be that merging two species will
require evolving them, then maybe the idea of merging
very different species is more a difference in degree
rather then a difference in kind.

--

    Note that merging can be preserving or
destructive.  By this I refer to whether the
individuals in the parent species will or will not get
the chance to survive the merge.  The significance of
this is that if Species-B has nothing to contribute to
fitness, then a preserving merge of A and B will
result in a new species identical, or strongly
resembling A.  And definitely as fit as A.  Whereas a
destructive merge may "damage" A as a result of
forcing it to merge with B.  Note that the less-fit
species is not guarranteed to survive in either
case...

    Ok, so ideas for merging:

1) union merge - just put all the individuals into a
single species, call the merge done and rely on
further normal genetics to finish the merge.

    - obviously if you have fixed size species you
will need to halve the size of the new one:

    i) take the best 50% of each input species
    ii) take the best 50% of the combined species (no,
these are not the same)
    iii) take only the two champions and let their
interaction refill the new species
    iv) allow an oversize species and decrease it
slowly over time

2) special union merge - as above, but setup special
breeding conditions for the period following the
merge, e.g. maybe turn down (of off) mutation and
focus only on cross-over...

    [[ these are all preserving ]]

3) pairwise breed merge - draw random pairs from the
two input species, crossbreed them once and place the
offspreing into the new one

    - this preserves the species size, if your
crossbreed method is non-deterministic you might want
to repeat each breeding M times and insert only the
fittest into the new species, although this might br
overkill because the new species will not go on to
breed in its own right and thus generate some of that
variation.

    [[ destructive ]]

4) all-all breed merge - crossbreed every individual
from species A with every individual from species B
and keep only the N fitest individuals from the whole
process

    - optionally repeat each crossbreeding M times but
only take the fittest offspring

    [[ destructive ]]

5) champion breed merge - take the highest scoring M
individuals from each species and crossbreed them to
produce the new species

    - if M = sqrt(n) and we crossbreed every possible
pair we get back to N individuals

    [[ destructive ]]

6) influence merge - continue to run one species as
normal, but make members of the other available as
parents

    - this has the effect of presenting a constant
influence from the constant second species onto the
first.  Genes from the second will make there way into
the first, and the first may evolve ways to exploit
them.

    [[ preserving for the first species ]]

--

    One idea that might have some use for
breeding-based merges is "asymmetric parentage".  This
is simply the idea that one partent might be a lesser
contributor to the ofspring than the other. 
Traditional NEAT has this in as much as where genes
are present in both parents, the copy from the fitter
parent is taken in preference to the one from the
other.  It gives the less-fit parent equal weighting
when it takes all unpaired genes from both parents,
however...

    Asymmetric parentage becomes useful if we accept
the idea that some genes from the one species might be
adaptive transferred into the other, while others were
very unadaptive.  With equal parentage, to discover
this we need to (i) crossbreed two individuals and
then (ii) delete the deadly genes (even assuming the
intermediate individual is fit enough to get
considered for mutation; and that you have
delete/disable mutations).

    With asymmetric parentage, if the second parent
has a weight of (say) 0.1, then on average a sample of
10% of its genes will appear in the offspring.  As
long as you are prepared to try the same crossbreeding
several times, this gives you a far better chance of
pulling out only the useful one(s)...

--

    As you might guess, this is for SLEAT and at
present I just have a union merge, which I didn't see
working very well yet, but then again I wouldn't
expect it to until the system has got sufficiently
stuck as to need a "step-aside" speciation, and that
probably needs me to run it for 10,000,000 cycles...

    As usual, any thoughts gratefully recieved...

    Ian
